dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Damn. He reaches for the car door, and we cut to:

dialogues.speaker: THE FRONT DOOR OF THE HOUSE SWINGING OPEN
dialogues.text: To reveal CATHERINE HOBBES, glaring at Dylan furiously.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: You were supposed to be here at seven o’clock. Last night.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry Catherine. Something came up at work, and...

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: It was an emergency, damnit. I don’t work delivering goddamn pizza! If something happens I... Then Dylan catches himself, seeing the LITTLE GIRL sittin the table beyond Catherine; her eyes are on her plate, tr to ignore her parents’ fight. DYLAN (CONT’D) You’re not keeping me from my daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dylan steps into the sunny space and sits down across fro his morose daughter, whose name is HANNA. He smiles tight

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Hey, baby. Sorry I couldn’t make it last night. But I got us all hooked up for the weekend, and-  ll.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: You’re never getting back together with Mom, are you? Dylan is silent, caught off guard. HANNA (CONT’D) What did you do to make her so mad at you?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Mom threw you out because you didn’t do your homework?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Something like that. But I think this weekend I’m going to earn a little extra credit. (smiles) We’re going to go to that new water- park, out on 66. Then... Then DYLAN’S CEL-PHONE BUZZES. Despite looks from both Hannah and Catherine, who is now in the kitchen doorway, Dylan looks down at the number -- His shoulders slump, an looks back up at his daughter: DYLAN (CONT’D) It’s an emergency. When it’s over, I’ll make it up to you... That’s a promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FBI AGENTS are seated around the room. The last to enter Dylan Hobbes -- still wearing the frustration of his morn on his face. TITLE: FBI Headquarters - Nevada Field Office  12. The air is filled with early morning banter. Standing in front of a MONITOR is SAC LOUIS HERNANDEZ.

dialogues.speaker: HERNANDEZ
dialogues.text: Nice of you to join us, Agent Hobbes. Alright, ladies, now that our star player is here, let’s cut the chatter- we got work to do. (the room quiets down) Got one for the X-Files, people. Our office in Paris called last night. There was a bank robbery there that took place about 7:30 a.m., Paris time. THE IMAGE OF MICHAEL ATLAS and the MAN FROM PARIS comes u the screen. HERNANDEZ (CONT’D) This is world famous magician Michael Atlas. The man with him is, as far as we know, a member of the audience from his show. When this image was captured, Atlas was on stage with the Four Horsemen, in the middle of their act at the MGM Grand. AGENT FULLER, a big bear of a man, mumbles from the back:

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER
dialogues.text: You’re saying these guys robbed a Paris bank -- from Vegas?

dialogues.speaker: HERNANDEZ
dialogues.text: I’m saying that’s what it looks like. ON THE MONITOR the audience in the theatre leap and scram for the MONEY fluttering down from above:

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Was it real?

dialogues.speaker: HERNANDEZ
dialogues.text: Was what real?  13.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: The money. Falling from the ceiling. Was it real or funny money?

dialogues.speaker: HERNANDEZ
dialogues.text: From the little we were able to recover- real as a heart attack.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER
dialogues.text: So they pull this thing off, and don’t even keep the score? Who are these guys?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: More pertinently- where are they?

dialogues.speaker: HERNANDEZ
dialogues.text: They’re staying in the Excelsior Hotel. Got the entire top floor rented out. We called, and they’re there. So they don’t appear to be particularly worried about all this. Another AGENT stands:

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Well, what are we waiting for?

dialogues.speaker: HERNANDEZ
dialogues.text: For Inspector Alma Vargas, of the Las Vegas Special Investigation Unit, to brief us so we know exactly what we’re dealing with. She’ll be liaising with us on this case. Inspector..? ALMA VARGAS, a beautiful young detective with a caustic attitude stands, aware of the instant attention she comma from all the men in the room; not necessarily for the thi she wants to be noticed for. She’s used to it. Alma press a remote, and an image of THE FOUR HORSEMEN appears on th

dialogues.text: The Four Horsemen are like a magic superhero team. Each one of them was an established magician in his own right before they joined forces, for what they’re billing as three special shows over the span of ten days. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Last night being the first. Friday they’re in Atlantic City, Wednesday next, in Los Angeles...

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: -Wow. You read the brochure. How did you manage to do all this “research,” Inspector?

dialogues.text: Police officers in Vegas are used to working late hours. Unlike FBI agents, apparently. Alex throws the ball into the glove again; then smiles an opens the glove-_the ball has disappeared. dialogues.text: In Paris? While we were in Las Vegas?  23. Alma Vargas is holding another can of diet coke. She shak it, hears nothing, so she peels off the cap and takes a s

dialogues.text: Confederates? You have the bank video. You saw what everyone else saw.

dialogues.text: Which was Michael Atlas and a member- purported- member of your audience, in the vault. In Paris.

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: Which is impossible, of course. (smiles) You think I built a transporter, like in a science fiction movie? I’m good, but no one is that good.

dialogues.text: Michael Atlas sits comfortably in his chair, in his t-shi and jeans:  25.

dialogues.text: -- My lawyers are better than your lawyers. Better paid, better dressed and better prepared. Which is what it’s all about, isn’t it? Preparation. We’re prepared. You’re not. dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: You are one cocky son of a bitch, aren’t you? In fact you are a quartet of cocky sons of bitches.

dialogues.text: That’s why we get paid the big bucks.

dialogues.text: So what did you need the money for? Why risk everything on a stunt like this?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL ATLAS
dialogues.text: You seem to be forgetting we don’t have the money.

dialogues.text: Not all of it. But hardly any of the cash that fell on that audience in your little Robin Hood bit was recovered. You could have kept the lion’s share for yourselves, for all we know. Michael turns his eyes on Alma, studies her carefully.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL ATLAS
dialogues.text: It’s clear, detective Vargas, that all you know does not amount to very much. There’s no way to tie the money we- donated- with the money from the bank. Unless you can put me in that vault, you’ve got nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: We have Etienne Glickman.  26. Michael raises his eyebrows, as if to ask- "Who?” ALMA VARGAS (CONT’D) The “audience member” you brought up onto the stage. Your plant.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL ATLAS
dialogues.text: Plant? The little French guy? You don’t know the first thing about magic, do you? What good could he possibly have been to me as plant? (smiles) Obviously you haven’t questioned him yet. I wish I could be there for that one. I haven’t had a good laugh in a while.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER
dialogues.text: You should check out Jerry at the Sands. It’s a goddam laugh riot.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL ATLAS
dialogues.text: So I’ve heard. But I’ma compulsive workaholic. It’s a failing of mine. So unless you have a better hand than the one you’ve been showing, I’d like to get out of here and start rehearsals for our next show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dylan, Alma, Agent Fuller and several others are sitting around, surrounded by empty fast food containers, looking beat. A RE-RUN of Michael Atlas’s interrogation is playin on a monitor. One of the agents groans:

dialogues.speaker: FBI AGENT
dialogues.text: I can’t watch this again. What a prick.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: They were all pricks. Like they were trying to piss us off on purpose.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER
dialogues.text: Nothing like rock stars, though. Remember when we had to bring in U2? Now those guys took it toa whole other level of prickness.  27.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: Prickishness.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: You said “prickness.” That’s not a word. The word is “prickishness.”

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER
dialogues.text: Whoa. Sorry to have blundered into your area of expertise. ON THE MONITOR: Michael Atlas grins and says:

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL ATLAS, (ON MONITOR)
dialogues.text: -- You don’t know the first thing about magic, do you?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He’s right, of course. You people really don’t know the first thing about magic... Every head in the room turns, to see

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS BRADLEY
dialogues.text: Standing in the doorway of the operations room:

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: -- But I do. I trust you’1ll excuse me for letting myself in unannounced.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER
dialogues.text: Who the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: Thaddeus Bradley. Probably the most hated magician on the planet.

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: My reputation precedes me. Still, “Hate” might be too strong a word.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: Actually, considering how many sneaky, vindictive weirdos do hate you, I’m amazed you’re still alive.  28.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Am I missing something here? You know this guy?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: Only from T.V. -- And Wikipedia. (turns to Dylan) I work entertainment in Las Vegas, agent Hobbes. It’s my job to know who’s who in town, so that when something like this goes down, not everyone is playing catch up. (then) -Even if it is at the expense of a less exciting social life. Agent Fuller winces for Dylan, as Alma rises and walks to coffee machine. ALMA VARGAS (CONT’D) Thaddeus Bradley has been exposing other magicians’ secrets for years. Embarrassed them, really. Wickname is the career killer. He even had a low rated Fox Show for short spell, where he...

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: The ratings were fine. The network simply didn’t know where to place it. Not to mention my books, two of which sat on the New York Times non-fiction best seller list for months.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER
dialogues.text: Whatever. What I want to know is- what the hell are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: Isn’t it obvious? (then) I’ve seen countless people try to figure out the mechanisms of countless tricks -- Your faces are not exactly flushed with the thrill of success. Dylan shakes off his anger at Alma’s jibe, and faces Thaddeus.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: We’ll figure it out.  29.

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: It’ll take time. Time you don’t have. The clock is on. Three shows in ten days- what you saw was merely the warm up act.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER
dialogues.text: And you know this because-?

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: I know show business. The magic business, in particular. And because I know Michael Atlas. (pauses) He was my student. Perhaps my brightest. But everything he knows, he learned from me.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: And what’s in this for you?

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: Isn’t that obvious, as well? (no answer) Relevance. (gathers himself) I want my name mentioned in every press conference you give about this case; and when it’s solved, and the Four Horsemen are behind bars, I want to be given the credit for breaking it. That’s what’s in it for me.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER
dialogues.text: The FBI doesn’t work with circus freaks.

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: When in Rome...

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: I’ll run it by brass. Leave your information and we’ll contact you. But before you do that, given the day I’ve had, I want you to know one thing... (pauses) If you point your finger at my pocket, and I reach in there and find your card, I swear on my mother I will shoot you where you stand.  30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LEAR JET THUNDERS OVERHEAD -- Touching down on the tarm and we cut to: THE FOUR HORSEMEN exiting their private jet, luggage in h They walk toward a BLACK LIMOUSINE waiting for them nearb

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE LIMOUSINE glides toward the lights of ATLANTIC CITY glittering in the near distance; we hear on the SOUNDTRAC

dialogues.speaker: RADIO D.J., (V.0.)
dialogues.text: -- Let’s cut to the chase: I know you're never gonna tell us how you did it, or even if you did it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FOUR HORSEMEN are seated around an interview table, facing the excitable young D.J., who continues: RADIO D.J. -- So the question I have to ask you is- Are you gonna do it again? London Osborne leans toward his mic and smiles:

dialogues.speaker: LONDON
dialogues.text: Come see our show Friday night and find out.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Word. I’11 be doing my song, too, from my new album- “Alex Hero steals your Heart”- so bum rush it, ladies.

dialogues.speaker: IMAGES, AS THE INTERVIEW CONTINUES ON
dialogues.text: SOUNDTRACK -- Dozens of RADIO STATION PHONE OPERATORS tak CALLS, typing in names and addresses into their computers

dialogues.speaker: RADIO D.J., (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The tickets to this show are being picked by random lottery, and are completely free, isn’t that right?

dialogues.speaker: LONDON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: That's right. Gift to our fans, from the Horsemen and our sponsors, the good people at Stonebridge Life.  31. LOTTERY BALLS WITH NAMES ON THEM FLY around inside an AIR CHAMBER, on a local MORNING SHOW -- Alex Hero reaches in snatches out ball after ball, watched by the show’s HOSTS

dialogues.speaker: RADIO D.J., (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We have two hundred seats available for our listeners right here, so call in if you want to see this incredible -- event. I’m not sure you can even call it just a “magic show” anymore... A COMPUTER IMAGE OF A THEATER SEATING PLAN fills the scre as SEAT AFTER SEAT IS FILLED UP, turning from blue to red RADIO D.J. (V.0.) (CONT’D) Some call you illusionists, some call you magicians; now some are calling you criminals. What do you have to say about that? THE COMPUTER IMAGE DISSOLVES into a HIGH ANGLE of the ACT AUDITORIUM, filled with empty red seats -- A LONE FIGURE steps onto the dark stage, becoming recognizable as MICHA ATLAS.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL ATLAS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: A man was nailed to a cross once. Killed in broad daylight by the powers that be. He was laid to rest inside of a dark cave, and the entrance was covered over with a rock. Three days later, he was gone... DOLLY IN ON MICHAEL as he takes in the dark theater:

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL ATLAS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It took Jesus three days to get out of an escape proof vault, and they said he was the son of God. I can do it three minutes -- So what does that make me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES TOWARD an upper floor WINDOW, as we hear DYL

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch...  32. INT. SECTION CHIEF’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS Dylan, Alma Vargas, and Agent Fuller are standing in fron SAC Hernandez; Dylan fumes:

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: -- I’ve never seen a guiltier bunch of perps in my life, and we let them fly off to Atlantic city just like that.

dialogues.speaker: HERNANDEZ
dialogues.text: Then make the case. Right now all they’re guily of is being a bunch of cocky bastards. (angry) They don’t have to prove they didn’t do it. We have to prove they did. Our job is harder, and it pays less. Way of the world. (then) What about their staff? Stagehands? Employees?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: We have whatever personnel we can spare on it, but-

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: Cogs in a machine. The Horsemen employ dozens of people at any given show; each person seems to know just enough to allow them to do their job. Maybe somebody’s wise to something, but I doubt it. And magic people are a tight lipped bunch, as it is. I doubt we’ll get far. Certainly not in three days.

dialogues.speaker: HERNANDEZ
dialogues.text: So that’s it? That’s all you got?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER
dialogues.text: We still got the French guy.

dialogues.speaker: HERNANDEZ
dialogues.text: Not for long. Got a call from the State Department. Either you pin something on him that can stick, or he’s on tonight’s flight back to the land of frog legs and cheese.  33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ETIENNE GLICKMAN, exhausted and irate, is sitting opposit the table from Alma, who is alone in the room with him.

dialogues.speaker: ETIENNE GLICKMAN
dialogues.text: I told you once, I told you twice, I’1l tell you an ‘undred times: I was in the theater, here in Las Vegas, yes? They call me to the stage, they wrap me in a fabric, and suddenly I am in a small room with a nice couch, where I am served coffee and cakes by a pretty girl. Not as pretty as you, but pretty enough-

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: I’m sure she was. Go on, Mr. Glickman.

dialogues.speaker: ETIENNE GLICKMAN
dialogues.text: After a few minutes the lights are turned off and I find myself back on the stage next to Mr. Atlas. Money is falling everywhere, everyone is going mad, and no one cares about me anymore. Finis. Alma turns to a MONITOR on which video from the Parisian vault is playing:

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: Are you saying that is not you?

dialogues.speaker: ETIENNE GLICKMAN
dialogues.text: Yes. I mean, it looks like me, but it is not me. I don’t even remember the last time I went into the bloody bank, I only use the ATM...

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: We ran a scan on your voice from the tape, Mr. Glickman, and it matches up as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dylan and Agent Fuller and several others are watching on monitor outside the interrogation room:  34.

dialogues.speaker: ETIENNE GLICKMAN, (ON MONITOR)
dialogues.text: It’s a trick, no? Do you think I really traveled through dimensions? That is what these people do- magic tricks. I’m a law abiding man, it’s not my job to know how they do these things. If you are too stupid to figure it out, it’s not my problem... Dylan and Agent Fuller turn away from the monitor, look a each other. They know what they have to do.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER
dialogues.text: shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THADDEUS BRADLEY walks into the auditorium where Dylan, A Fuller and Alma are waiting, standing near the empty stag

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: My name. Correctly pronounced, every time a press conference is given. Correctly spelled in every press release. And credit for...

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: For “breaking the case.” Done. But the case has to get broken first.

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: And the reason for meeting in such theatrical environs?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER
dialogues.text: You’re going to show us how they pulled it off, right?

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: And you think anything on this stage or auditorium had anything to do with it? (sighs) You really are an organization of rubes, aren’t you? I’m surprised anyone ever gets caught at all...

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Are you breaking some kind of magician’s code if you aren’t acting like a complete asshole? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (steps close to Thaddeus) You don’t start coming up with the goods, right now, I’m gonna call the IRS and have them back audit you for every fiscal year of your goddamn pathetic life. How’s that for a trick? Thaddeus locks eyes with Dylan -- Not someone to be trifl with, either. Then:

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: The first mistake one could make would be to assume that the robbery actually occurred on the night of the performance -- when it happened some seventy six hours earlier. With the preparations for it taking up at least the better part of the week, on the streets of Paris. IMAGE OF MICHAEL ATLAS, RODERIGO AND LONDON OSBORNE walki through the crowded throng on the CHAMPS ELYSEES, blendin with minimal disguises; a baseball hat, sunglasses, etc.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We might be rubes, but we’re not stupid. That's the first thing we checked. The Horsemen haven't left the country in months. And-

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And fake passports are so hard to pull off? BACK TO DYLAN: Shaking his head:

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: They are, these days.

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: Well, that would be your area of expertise more than mine, wouldn’t it, Agent Hobbes? I am simply here to tell you that somehow it was accomplished, and-

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Uh uh. They’ve been here in Vegas rehearsing their show for the past few weeks. There are plenty of witnesses who saw them every day...  36. IMAGES OF MEMBERS OF THE HORSEMEN in various locations, s from the POV’s OF NEARBY SPECTATORS: RODERIGO, rehearsing the gears of a gimmick on-stage; LONDON OSBORNE, walking purposefully through a casino mall; MICHAEL ATLAS, gettin takeout at a restaurant, waving to a fan...

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Talk to the those witnesses again. Ask them if they saw more than one of the Horsemen at a time, and how close they got to them.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: You're saying one of these guys stayed behind and disguised himself as the other guys for an alibi?

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Is that so difficult to conceive? Speaking of which, did you enjoy your interrogation of that poor French fellow? What was his name?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Glickman. Etienne Glickman. IMAGES OF ETIENNE GLICKMAN walking blithely through th atreet in PARIS -- RODERIGO is following him, snapping with a powerful POCKET CAMERA; ALSO SNAPPING PHOTOS 0: SEVERAL OTHER MEN HE IS SHADOWING...

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Tickets for the Horsemen's shows are sold long in advance. In August there are plenty of French tourists in Vegas. I imagine they advertised heavily on the streets of Paris all of July... IT’S TRUE: As Roderigo follows a man in the metro, he pas a large BILLBOARD for the FOUR HORSEMEN on the wall of th station. THADDEUS (V.O.) (CONT’D) -- They checked the names on the credit card reservations from Paris; then followed those men, photographed several of them to be safe in case of a cancellation, and created make-up for each one...  37.

dialogues.speaker: THE PHOTOS OF FIVE FRENCH MEN- ETIENNE GLICKMAN AMONG THE
dialogues.text: ADORN A WALL, below which a pair of dextrous HANDS prepar rubber molds and fake hair for disguises. THADDEUS (V.O.) (CONT’D) -- The make-up would only need to be minimally suggestive, given the quality of the security camera image. On the night of the robbery they repeated their little act for the camera three or four times with several different make-ups, and used the tape of Mr. Glickman only when they saw he was at the show...

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. That doesn’t wash. Even with make-up, how would they know what he’d be wearing on the night of the show?

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: They couldn't, of course. Why do you think they put him in that ridiculous red jumpsuit before “transporting” him? You didn’t think it was actually for-

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Traveling through dimensions? No we did not, Mr. Bradley. Please continue.

dialogues.speaker: IMAGES OF ETIENNE GLICKMAN BEING WRAPPED IN THE JUMPSUIT
dialogues.text: then of SOMEONE DISGUISED AS HIM in the security camera footage, wearing the red jumpsuit -- then the same thing repeated with several different “disguises.”

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The first thing to look for in any illusion is, what is essential and what ig not? Anything that isn’t, disguised as showmanship, is there for a very specific purpose. In this case the red jumpsuit was put on to cover the clothing, its garishness to draw attention from the face and the hastily applied make-up.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Why bother with the whole French guy schtick, in the first place?  38.

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: To make the illusion real. To make the audience, and you, think what they were seeing was taking place then and there.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: What about the voice match? IMAGE OF MICHAEL ATLAS standing next to ETIENNE GLICKMAN bistro, as he orders a coffee -- IN MICHAEL’S SHOULDER BA a RECORDING DEVICE.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: That wouldn’t be much of a problem. If they were tailing these guys, they could've easily recorded their voices and cut something together later...

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: What I want to know is, how did they get him to vanish off the stage like that? BACK IN THE THEATER: Dylan and Alma turn and look at Full with raised eyebrows: AGENT FULLER (CONT’D) (defensive) What?

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: For questions like that I refer you to the box set of the first season of my show-

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: There only was one season.

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: -Available for thirty nine ninety five on Amazon, or on my website. Am I here to teach you parlor tricks or help you solve a crime?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Which you said happened seventy two hours earlier. How did you come up with that number? IMAGE OF THE FRENCH GUARDS opening the vault door, runnin inside, only to cough and gag at the FUMES in the air...  33.

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If you examine the vault with those scientific instruments you people are so proud of, I believe you'll find traces of dioxide hydrosulfate. Known colloguially in my circles as "Vanishing Juice.” IMAGES OF HUGE WADS OF EUROS being doused in a chemical b THADDEUS (V.O.) (CONT’D) When paper of a certain make is treated with it, it instigates a chemical reaction that causes complete disintegration, accompanied by rather noxious fumes, exactly eighty hours later. Like milk curdling on a dime. Illusionists have been using it for centuries. The thing is, you have to time your gag just right, or you might miss the moment... IN THE VAULT, WE SEE MICHAEL ATLAS and the disguised MAN PARIS replacing the EUROS that are there with different E from their own bags. THADDEUS (CONT’D) They made counterfeit cash out of this paper- and I'll thank you not to ask me how counterfeit cash is made. They treated it several hours before entering the vault, then switched it with the real money, so that no one would notice anything was missing. In the minimum time remaining they escaped with the real cash, made it to Vegas and on-stage in time for the show. They do their bit, the guards in Paris fling open the vault door and on cue- pffff. There must have been a lot of Credit Lyonnais customers wondering what was happening in their wallets that MOINING««+ IMAGES of FUMES POURING FROM PARISIANS’ POCKETS -- WALLET SMOKING in people’s hands, CASH DISSOLVING IN FRONT OF TH EYES...

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: They still had to rob that bank.  40. BACK TO THADDEUS: He turns to Dylan and sighs:

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: Which is, again, your area of expertise. You are going to earn some of your meager salary, aren’t you, Agent Hobbes?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: You say the Horsemen didn’t know which guy from the audience they would use until the last minute. Yet the bank’s tape showed Michael Atlas and Etienne Glickman in the vault. That means someone had to be there, at the time of the performance, to put that tape in their system. Which means they had an accomplice on the inside.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: The French cops ran polygraphs on the bank guards. They all passed with flying colors.

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: (to Alma) Not bad, detective. I believe you to be correct. But it was not necessarily a willing accomplice. Or should I say, a conscious one... IMAGE OF THE BANK GUARD CAPTAIN, receiving a phone call; scene we saw earlier, right after the performance:

dialogues.speaker: GUARD CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: <Hallo? No we haven’t opened yet.> (listens) <From Las Vegas? In America? That’s ridiculous...> CUT TO LONDON OSBORNE, on his cel-phone, walking toward t LIMOUSINE in the MGM GRAND PARKING AREA where the other Horsemen are waiting for him:

dialogues.speaker: LONDON, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: (In French) <Pineapple. You understand?>

dialogues.speaker: GUARD CAPTAIN, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: <Of course. JI understand. Right away.>  41. IN THE BANK SECURITY OFFICE: The GUARD CAPTAIN, now looki somewhat dazed, hangs up the phone. Walks to a drawer nea opens it, and finds a TAPE waiting for him. He picks it u moves to the BANK OF MONITORS, and pops out the OLD TAPE.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Okay. Here’s where I draw the dine... BACK IN THE MGM THEATER: Dylan is shaking his head, he’s heard enough: DYLAN (CONT’D) -- You want me to believe that some guy could be hypnotized days in advance to respond to a code word, like something out of “The Manchurian Candidate?” I thought you exposed tricks, man.

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: Mentalism- guessing the future and the card in your hand and all that- depends on tricks. Hypnotism is the real deal... IMAGE OF LONDON OSBORNE, disguised as a repair-man, talki earnestly to the GUARD CAPTAIN OF THE BANK; behind them w SEE ALEX HERO, slipping past unseen, sliding a TAPE INTO DRAWER in the back. THADDEUS (V.O.) (CONT’D) -- Practiced by an expert it’s an extremely potent method of inducing its subject to action. Especially action which falls within the scope of the subject’s usual patterns... BACK TO THADDEUS: We move in his darkly intelligent eyes, voice soft: THADDEUS (CONT’D) You referred to us as “circus freaks,” as I recall. So I will tell you this- (pauses) London Osborne is the best at what he does. Much as I dislike these boys, they all are. Their next show is in less than forty eight hours. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THADDEUS (CONT’D) Were I in your shoes, I would not make the mistake of underestimating them. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: A CROWD OF EXCITED FANS
dialogues.text: Mostly women, holding signs adorned with images of the FO HORSEMEN, chanting their names; seen through the glass do of a hotel lobby -- SUPERIMPOSE TITLE: Trump Hotel - Atlantic City - Friday DOLLY OVER to find DYLAN HOBBES, standing at a PAY-PHONE:

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: -- I’m sorry Hanna... I am so sorry I can’t be there this weekend. I’m working... I have to catch some bad men, and- (listens) Yeah, I know you’re not a child. Yeah, yeah, I know you’re not a retard... I don’t mean to talk to you like one. I’m trying to catch those guys, the ones on the news... (beat) No, they are not f-ing cool. Don’t use that kind of language. They’re criminals, and I’m gonna catch them. And- Hanna? Hanna... A beat. Dylan hangs up the phone; looks like he’s thinkin dialing again... but doesn’t. He walks over to where ALMA VARGAS is waiting.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: Payphone?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: My wife- ex-wife- hangs up when she sees my number. If I catch her off- guard I can usually talk my way into a conversation with my little girl. Alma studies Dylan, then looks out at the crowd, shaking head:

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: It’s like Beatlemania or something. (then) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You think Thaddeus is right? That they’re going to try it again?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: That’s why we’re here, isn’t it? THADDEUS BRADLEY is visible across the hotel lobby, talki to the concierge.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: Do you trust him?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Not sure. Which is why we brought him here, but didn’t give him anything to do. I’m gonna shadow him- see if he leads us to water. You wait for the Horsemen to come down, stay on them from the minute they leave the hotel -- Got Fuller and the others situated between here and the theater... Alma nods, but Dylan doesn’t leave; there is some electricity in the air between them: DYLAN (CONT’D) Listen, detective Varg... Alma. Since joining the bureau I haven’t, well, interfaced with LVPD, not since I was a cop myself. I just want you to know, that, well-

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: Do you really need it, Agent Hobbes?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Need what?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: Another excuse not to spend time with your daughter. Dylan is stung silent. Then his eyes shift, as he sees: THADDEUS BRADLEY buttoning up his jacket and exiting the hotel through a side door, heading out into the street. Dylan turns without another word and follows after Bradle

dialogues.speaker: HOLD ON ALMA
dialogues.text: Feeling she might have gone too far, and we cut to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HUGE CROWD is gathered beneath the marquee, which reads STONEBRIDGE LIFE presents THE FOUR HORSEMEN -- AGENT FULL scans the area, and speaks into his CEL-PHONE:

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER
dialogues.text: Yo, Dylan. Hours before showtime, and there’s already a huge freakin’ crowd here. We’re in the wrong business. You on the old freak?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dylan is moving through the densely crowded space, keepin distance between himself and Thaddeus; he whispers into h ear-piece:

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Yeah- But this guy has eyes in the back of his head. Try not to... (then) Hold on, I’ve got a text. Damn. Cathy, busting my balls for calling Hanna, and- Dylan looks up- he was just distracted for an instant- bu his face fills with concern: DYLAN (CONT’D) Shit. I’ve lost him. Shit.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: What do you mean lost him?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: I mean he’s gone. I will call you back. Shit.. Shit... Dylan hurries into the crowd, looking in every direction, trying at the same time not to make himself too conspicuo the sound of the crowd growing louder and louder, and we a hard cut to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Alma sits on a stool at the bar, nursing a half- finished DIET-COKE. Sips at it. Calls to the BARTENDER:

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: Excuse me- this soda is kinda flat.  45.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: You been working on it for a while. She starts to answer, when the SWEATY BUSINESSMAN next to gets his courage up enough to make conversation:

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: In town for the show, right?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: For the magic show. Or just here to try your luck?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: Little bit of both.

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: Robin Hoods, right? (Alma raises an eyebrow) Steal from the rich, right? Why should those scumbags have it all, right? Spread the goods. Socialism my ass. Spread it around, right? Alma doesn’t know what to answer- then there is a TREMEND SHOUT from outside, and she turns to see THE FOUR HORSEMEN exiting the elevator into the lobby, flanked by a PHALANX OF SECURITY; they move toward the fr doors, as the excited crowd outside presses in towards th

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: (into her ear-piece) In case anyone was wondering what that earthquake was -- They’re on the move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALMA pushes autographs, them; there

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE HOTEL
dialogues.text: her way out into the crowd, as the magicians sign making their way toward the limousine waiting for is media everywhere. NEWSCASTER’S VOICE OVER THE  46.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -- The Four Horsemen, getting a reception usually reserved for rock stars, prepare to head to the historic Paradise Theater, and every bank, everywhere, is on high alert -- Whatever these self-styled maverick magicians have planned, this time it will certainly have to be done without the benefit of the element of surprise...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA LOOKS up at the towering building, and THE FIGURE MAN steps into frame, stopping to let the traffic pass in front of him. Hold on his back, as we SUPERIMPOSE THE TIT New York City - That Very Moment The figure steps forward, crosses the street, and enters front doors of the massive building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The walks up to the security desk, and stops in front of

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: Can I help you? REVERSE ON THE MAN -- Glasses, mustache, nondescript. We we’ve seen him before; in fact, that he is someone we kno but in disguise. We just can’t tell who. He speaks with a strange off-kilter accent:

dialogues.speaker: DISGUISED MAN
dialogues.text: I’m going up to my office.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: And you are-?

dialogues.speaker: DISGUISED MAN
dialogues.text: (showing ID) Kaplan. George Kaplan. The Security Guard processes the ID; then:

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: Nice to finally meet you, Mr. Kaplan.  47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “Mr. Kaplan” exits the elevator, putting on a pair of FLE COLORED LATEX GLOVES, as he walks across the hallway towa glass door on which the logo is printed: KAPLAN INC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kaplan enters, and the YOUNG WOMAN behind the recepti desk, A TEMP, looks up, almost surprised:

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TEMP
dialogues.text: Hello? Can I help you, Mr..?

dialogues.speaker: MR. KAPLAN
dialogues.text: Kaplan. You can call me George.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TEMP
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Kaplan. I was wondering if anyone ever came to work here. I don’t even think I’ve gotten a phone call since I-

dialogues.speaker: MR. KAPLAN
dialogues.text: Slow times. You can go home now, I won’t be needing you anymore.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TEMP
dialogues.text: Should I come in tomorrow? Because I should tell the agency my...

dialogues.speaker: MR. KAPLAN
dialogues.text: That won’t be necessary. I’11l make sure to tell the temp agency you did a bang up job. The temp rises, gathering her things, then:

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TEMP
dialogues.text: If you don’t mind my asking, what is it you do around here, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: MR. KAPLAN
dialogues.text: Oh, you know. A little of this, a little of that. (smiles) Good night.  48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kaplan steps into the spacious, but almost bare offic There is a single desk in the middle of the room, with a laptop computer and a telephone on it -- Mr. Kaplan sits the desk, looks up a phone number, then picks up the phon dials, and:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN OFFICE ASSISTANT picks up the phone; behind her we can see the logo for STONEBRIDGE LIFE:

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Arthur Tressler’s office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kaplan speaks into the phone with a completely differ accent:

dialogues.speaker: MR. KAPLAN
dialogues.text: Hi Julie, this is Stewart, from Four Horsemen management. I just wanted to check if Mr. Tressler will be at the show tonight, and see if there’s anything further we can do for him?

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Mr. Tressler’s already in Atlantic City. Thanks for calling- if he needs anything, we’ll let you know.

dialogues.speaker: MR. KAPLAN
dialogues.text: My pleasure. He hangs up the phone. Then he opens up a drawer, where w see a number of KEYS, ACCESS CARDS, AND MINI-HARD DRIVES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kaplan turns the corner and stops in front of the SER ELEVATOR. He takes out a key, and turns it in the elevato lock...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kaplan comes out of the service elevator and into the corridor. He stops in front of a back door, swipes the electronic LOCK with an ACCESS CARD, and enters  49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- a hallway in a modern, corporate space. He walks casua down the hall, then stops at the corner, cautiously peeri around it, to see THE OFFICE ASSISTANT he was just speaking to at her desk front of the STONEBRIDGE LIFE logo -- The two offices are the same building. Mr. Kaplan looks to the side, where he see a FIRE ALARM o the wall beside him; he contemplates it for a second, the shakes his head at the vulgarity of the idea. He turns ba toward the assistant’s desk -- sees there is a MAN workin late in another office. So Mr. Kaplan clears his throat, gauges the angle, and speaks at a volume (“throwing his voice”) that makes it seem like his voice is coming from MAN’S OFFICE:

dialogues.speaker: MR. KAPLAN
dialogues.text: Hey, Julie- can you come here for a minute? The assistant gets up and walks to the far office; and li wisp of smoke Mr. Kaplan glides by behind her and walks t the door of Tressler’s office -- It’s locked. He quickly takes out a SKELETON KEY, slides it into the lock, opens door and slips into the office, quickly closing the door behind himself with hardly a sound...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CROWD filing in is subjected to metal-detector search by SECURITY GUARDS at the doors; THADDEUS BRADLEY allows himself to be searched, then strolls into the lobby, and

dialogues.speaker: RACK FOCUS TO
dialogues.text: ALMA VARGAS, holding her ever-present diet Coke; she noti Thaddeus entering, then she turns as DYLAN steps up besid her:

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Anything interesting?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: Not unless you count the magical way the bubbles seem to disappear from the diet Coke around here. Our boys went backstage as soon as they arrived -- You?  50.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: I... lost Bradley. Just spotted him outside the theater ten minutes ago. He could have been anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HELICOPTER TOUCHES DOWN on the tarmac. A FIGURE hops ou and we see that it is “GEORGE KAPLAN”- who hurries into a waiting CAR, and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AGENT FULLER speaks into his cel-phone, bored as hell:

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER
dialogues.text: -- Nothing doing. No backstage traffic since the Horsemen came in. What the hell are we doing here, anyway? So maybe these guys robbed some French bank- who the hell cares? Let the goddam French deal with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE STAND-BY TICKET HOLDERS are being herded in by USHERS are doing their best to keep order:

dialogues.speaker: USHERS
dialogues.text: Stand-by tickets... Stand by ticket holders only. Dylan has his phone to his ear, Alma standing beside him:

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: It’s not just what they did -- It’s what they might do. Just chow down on some freedom fries and keep your eyes open. ANGLE BEHIND DYLAN: filing in unnoticed with the last of crowd, is “GEORGE KAPLAN”-- or at least he’s unnoticed by Dylan and Alma; for as he saunters into the theater, the

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS BRADLEY
dialogues.text: Sitting in a corner seat. As “George Kaplan” passes, Thad allows himself a smile.  51.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO DYLAN AND ALMA
dialogues.text: Dylan looks at his watch, mutters: DYLAN (CONT’D) Showtime. Either this is a big wank, or they’re so far ahead of us it isn’t funny.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: Oh, come on... Admit it.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Admit what?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: Part of you wants to see what these guys are going try to pull off, just like everyone else in here. (smiles) And we’ve got front row seats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOLLY BEHIND “GEORGE KAPLAN” as he hurries through the na corridor- he reaches up as he goes, pulling at his face, though we are behind him we see he is taking off his glasses... his mustache... strips of latex “skin”...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: START CLOSE ON ALEX HERO- making a deck of cards leap fro one hand to the other- like an athlete warming up; says:

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: This is bullshit. He could call. Doesn’t have to keep us in suspense and whatnot, like we’re a bunch of rubes. People wait on Alex Hero, not the other way around. CAMERA MOVES to RODERIGO, fixing his gaudy shirt in the mirror:

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: Talk about yourself in third person again, cabrone, you’ll be pulling those cards out of your ass. We did our jobs. He’ll do his. Either way, we have a show to do. CAMERA MOVES TO LONDON OSBORNE, sitting in his chair like zen-master:  52.

dialogues.speaker: LONDON
dialogues.text: Oh, we’re going full guns tonight. No doubt about that.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah? Why are you so sure about it?

dialogues.speaker: LONDON
dialogues.text: ‘Cause I can see the bloody future. LONDON LOOKS UP and the CAMERA FOLLOWS HIS LOOK TO THE DO which SWINGS OPEN AS IF ON CUE, revealing: MICHAEL ATLAS -- wiping off the last of his “George Kapla make-up.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL ATLAS
dialogues.text: Game on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SPECTACULAR LIGHTSHOW splits the darkness -- ACCOMPANIE the sounds of HEAVY METAL ROCK AND ROLL, and the FOUR HORSEMEN appear onstage looking out at the cheering crowd

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: Winecing at the music, disgusted, he wads up some toilet and sticks it into his ears, as MICHAEL ATLAS steps to th foot of the stage:

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL ATLAS
dialogues.text: Audiences for magic can be a tricky bunch. Some are happy to suspend their disbelief. Others are constantly looking for the rabbit under the hat, the trap door, the trick wire. You know who you are... (laughter from the crowd) As you all know, tonight is the second of our three shows, and we're lucky to have some special guests with us. There in back, sticking toilet paper in his ears, is none other than Thaddeus Bradley. He’ll be happy to tell you how he thinks we pulled off tonight’s show... if you can find his DVD’s buried in the back of the discount rack at your local video store.  53. SOME BOOS mixed with a few CHEERS. Thaddeus gives a wave the crowd. MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) We also have a contingent from the police and FBI with us. A pair of them right there in the front row; and a handsome couple they are, too. Wave to the nice officers... (the CROWD waves at ALMA

dialogues.speaker: AND DYLAN
dialogues.text: They will seek, but they shall not find. For tonight we inhabit the theater of mystery, where we are all once again wide-eyed children, awed by magic and wonder. Tonight -- The Four Horsemen ride.

dialogues.speaker: THE FANTASTIC SHOW
dialogues.text: RODERIGO “flies” above the audience, sailing over their delighted upturned faces... LONDON looks on as an obese man walks across the stage on hands, like a gymnast... A MERCIFULLY SHORT CLIP OF ALEX HERO singing the single m annoying song in the history of show business... MICHAEL ATLAS moves in front of a display of mirrors with audience member, their reflections behaving differently t their real-life counterparts onstage, and

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN AND ALMA
dialogues.text: Look at each other; there is a brief moment of tenderness between them. Almost like a date. Alma’s face tightens as she remembers something, and she whispers:

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: Hey. What I said to you before, about your daughter. I was out of line. I’m...

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: You were right. But thanks. Then the final illusion ends with a flash and the theater

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL ATLAS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, we're glad to have been able to take your mind off your troubles with an hour’s divertissement... THE LIGHTS COME BACK UP illuminating MICHAEL, in his T-sh and jeans, standing at the foot of the now bare stage. MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) But I can’t leave this stage in good conscience without acknowledging that we are living in troubled times... THE AUDIENCE ROARS IN ANTICIPATION at the sound of these words -- This is the moment they have been waiting for. MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) At this point I’d like to introduce our generous sponsor, Mr. Arthur Tressler, president of Stonebridge Life. The tickets tonight were free, but someone had to foot the bill. Where are you, Arthur? ARTHUR TRESSLER, sixties, slick white hair, kisses his TR GIRLFRIEND and stands, waving to the crowd. MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) Don’t sit down just yet, Arthur. We’re going to put you to work. (to the crowd) Our final number is called “The Case of the Vanishing Money”- Prosaic, I admit, but accurate. How many of you out there have your ATM cards with you? (hands go up) How many of you know your account balances? (many hands stay up) Arthur, would you be so good as to pick a volunteer from our audience? Everyone’s waving their bank cards -- Arthur Tressler spo and points at a middle aged, AFRICAN AMERICAN WOMAN. MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) Bring her on up, Arthur. Tressler somewhat reluctantly moves into the aisle and escorts the woman up to the stage.  55. MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) I can see Arthur has an eye for good looking ladies -- what’s your name, ma’am?

dialogues.speaker: AFRICAN-AMERICAN WOMAN
dialogues.text: Gloria.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL ATLAS
dialogues.text: Lovely name for a lovely lady. (to Tressler) And would you mind staying up here on stage with us for a bit, Arthur? (to the crowd) A big hand for Mr. Tressler! Tressler stays put, starting to chafe. Michael turns back Gloria: MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) How about that bank card? Gloria takes it out of her bag, and moves to hand it to Michael; but: MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) No, you hold on to that, Gloria. You know how much you have in your account?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Unfortunately I do. It’s only-

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL ATLAS
dialogues.text: -Hold on to that thought, Gloria. In the meantime, we’re going to bring out our own specially designed ATM machine -- Roderigo? RODERIGO SANTAYANA wheels out an old fashioned BLACKBOARD into the middle of the stage, to the laughter of the audience: MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) That’s it?

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: I’m on a budget, hombre. Michael turns to the other side of the stage:  56.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL ATLAS
dialogues.text: Alright, I’m gonna need a little extra help with this one. London? LONDON OSBORNE strolls over to the blackboard, as Michael turns back to the audience: MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) Remember, I did not pick Gloria. Our assistant for the evening, Mr. Arthur Tressler did. If you think he’s in on this... stick around. (then) Gloria, I want you to think of your password. LONDON takes out a piece of chalk, scribbles on the rever side of the blackboard. MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) Okay, you got it? (Gloria nods) London? London flips the blackboard over- he’s written “SNUFFLES” it with the chalk. Gloria’s eyes widen: MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) Sounds like a cutie. And your account balance is... LONDON SCRIBBLES on the other side, flips the board over, it shows: $19.46 MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) (winces) Okay. That’s a modest sum. Don’t you think so, Arthur?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR TRESSLER
dialogues.text: I... guess it is.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL ATLAS
dialogues.text: Actually it’s a crime, that’s what it is. (to Tressler) Would you like to hold up your ATM card for us, Arthur?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR TRESSLER
dialogues.text: No. I don’t suppose I would.  57. THE CROWD ERUPTS IN BOOS. Tressler grits his teeth, reach into his pocket, and takes out his ATM card, keeping it tightly gripped in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL ATLAS
dialogues.text: London, what is Mr. Tressler’s password? London scribbles on the back of the blackboard- flips it to reveal the word: ASSHOLE THE CROWD ERUPTS IN LAUGHTER -- Michael quiets them down, turns to London again: MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) And his current bank balance? London scribbles on the board, flips it over, and we see- 258,800,045. The crowd gasps. Michael smiles at Tressler: MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) Look about right? Minus the tip you gave the limo driver on the way over. Actually, I hear you’re a pretty lousy tipper.. (Tressler is now glaring at Michael in open fury) Ladies and gentlemen, our sponsor knows a little bit about magic as well. You see, Arthur Tressler likes to buy insurance companies at discounted prices, and then make their assets disappear. Well, they don’t really disappear: he takes those assets which are to be kept safe for payouts to his customers, and deposits them into his own accounts. And they call us crooks. London erases 800,000 from Tressler’s account on the boar then flips the board around, and shows that GLORIA’S ACCO is now showing $800,019.50. The crowd laughs; but: MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) I know... it’s just numbers on a blackboard. Mr. Tressler, would you care to check your bank balance? Tressler takes out his CELL-PHONE, presses a few numbers the screen; and suddenly  58. SCREENS ALL AROUND THE STAGE COME TO LIFE; replicating th IMAGE OF TRESSLER’S CELL-PHONE SCREEN. His account shows 258,000,045 -- Eight hundred thousand dollars are missing

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR TRESSLER
dialogues.text: This better be a joke, Atlas.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL ATLAS
dialogues.text: Or what? You’ll call the cops? They’re already here, remember? I’m sure they’1ll have plenty of questions for you on the way out. But before that... (to the audience) Everyone’s heard about all the money raining down at our last show- Due to circumstances beyond our control, that won’t be happening tonight. THE CROWD BOOS LOUDLY; Michael raises his hands: MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) But cash is so old school, don’t you think? Never let it be said the Four Horsemen don’t move with the times. (smiles) How many of you have these new- fangled phones with high speed internet and whatnot? A scattering of HANDS GO UP. MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) Allow me to bring the rest of you into the 21st Century. Would you all check you pockets... your hand- bags? ANGLES ON THE AUDIENCE: all finding NEW PHONES nestled in their pockets and personal belongings. MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) The X-Phone, made by Nakano- our new sponsor- which we’re gonna need, considering what’s about to happen to our old one. Now, if you turn those on, you’ll find all your information has been transferred to your new phones. Addresses, phone numbers and everything.  59.

dialogues.speaker: THE AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: As the phones are turned on, the darkness illuminated by blue screens like the sky being filled with a thousand st

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL ATLAS, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Tonight's audience was supposed to be chosen by a random drawing. But I have to admit, we cheated. Everyone here has one thing in common -- You're all customers of companies Arthur Tressler has purchased. You believed yourselves to be in good hands- but if you need a large payout there will be nothing in the bank.... ANGLES ON THE AUDIENCE: Distraught faces lit blue by the phones. MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) He’s been hustling you like a street-corner shell-game artist. When audited he moves the money from one account to another. He has robbed each and every one of you. (pauses) But fear not. Tonight this theater is a true house of magic... ANGLE ON DYLAN AND ALMA: looking around themselves, as th air is filled with glittering confetti that rises from th floor upwards -- the entire space filling with pixie dust MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) Let it surround you. And now access your accounts, and check your brand new bank balances.

dialogues.speaker: FINGERS PUNCH KEYBOARDS
dialogues.text: FILLING UP WITH LARGE NUMBERS -- WHILE THE SCREEN that ho TRESSLER’S ACCOUNT shows his number STEADILY DIMINISHING, cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR TRESSLER HIDING HIS FACE FROM A HUNDRED CAMERA FLA
dialogues.text: As he tries to get to his limo in the parking lot behind theater; being shouted from all directions... THE CAMERA BOOMS UP on the hectic scene, as Tressler is swallowed up the mass of cameras, reporters and surging onlookers; on

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: -- In a theatrical twist, Arthur Tressler, president of Stonebridge Life Insurance, was exposed as a criminal by the Four Horsemen, whose show was sponsored by his own company..+.+ TELEVISED IMAGE SHOWS A HUGE CROWD shouting at Tressler a holding up “FOUR HORSEMEN” banners:

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -- Meanwhile Horsemen fever is growing; once mere entertainers, they're quickly becoming folk heroes -- And with their third, and reportedly final show coming up in three days, the question on everyone’s mind is- can they top themselves? REVERSE SHOWS DYLAN AND ALMA at the BAR IN THE TRUMP HOTE watching the television with mixed emotions. Alma clicks her phone:

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: The Horsemen are in the air.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: On their way to LA.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: Our flight leaves in three hours. Dylan finishes his drink- turns to Alma.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: That leaves us with two hours. Alma hesitates, considering, then:

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: I know what it’s like, when things go bad in a marriage. When mine ended, well, let’s just say I was ho girl scout. I know this could be something more... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: {pauses) But I’ve spent the last five years of my life busting underage movie stars for doing coke and over the hill singers for doing underage girls, and all of them for driving under the influence afterwards. This is my first real case, and I won’t mess up because I’m being distracted by... personal matters. (meaningfully) Like you did. Alma leans close to Dylan, their lips almost touching. ALMA VARGAS (CONT’D) See you on the plane, Agent Hobbes. HOLD ON DYLAN’S FACE, as Alma walks away.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Talk about preparation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUICK IMAGES: FBI AGENTS milling around the space, dustin for fingerprints on the furniture, on the phones, while w hear AGENT FULLER ON THE SOUNDTRACK:

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: -- Some dummy company, Kaplan Inc., leased out office space in the Stonebridge Life building months before last night's show. They had access to the building; blueprints the entire space. They stole access cards, keys, you name it, and from internal phone records and security files, gained access to Stonebridge’s entire database as well... IMAGES OF AGENTS questioning a NUMBER OF YOUNG TEMPS, the we saw in the scene with “George Kaplan” among them: AGENT FULLER (V.0.) (CONT’D) -- They hired temps, never for more than three days at a time, none of whom ever saw anyone who worked at the company. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: On the night of the show, a Mr. George Kaplan finally put in an appearance, and apparently broke into Arthur Tressler's office, accessed his private computer and account...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agent Fuller finishes filling in Dylan, SAC Hernandez and Thaddeus Bradley:

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER
dialogues.text: -- and the rest is history.

dialogues.speaker: HERNANDEZ
dialogues.text: The money for the office rent came out of Stonebridge Life’s own coffers. These guys are real good, and they’re making us look real bad. (hard) Three days to their last show. We get caught with our pants down again, heads are gonna roll. Thaddeus Bradley is chuckling; the others turn to him:

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER
dialogues.text: What’s so goddamn funny?

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: “George Kaplan.”

dialogues.speaker: HERNANDEZ
dialogues.text: What about him?

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: I made Michael Atlas in disguise, slipping into the theater at the last minute before the show. Clearly, he got past your eagle- eyes without much of an effort.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Atlas was with the others from the moment they left the hotel. Inspector Vargas saw him with her own eyes.  63.

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: She saw someone disguised as Michael Atlas, while Atlas himself was in New York City, disguised as “George Kaplan.” (smiles) He always did have an unhealthy fascination with Cary Grant.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Alright. Maybe there is a Fifth Horseman. Probably the same one who was in disguise as the others in Vegas, while they were in Paris, pulling off the bank job, but-

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER
dialogues.text: Five Horsemen, six Horsemen... How do we know there aren’t ten of them? How do we know they’re not a front for a whole bunch of guys-?

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: Unlikely. I wouldn’t waste precious time contemplating it.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: What would you do, Bradley? I’m sick of you telling us what we don’t know, without giving us anything we can actually use -- For all we know you’re the Fifth Horseman.

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: Which is why you had me followed all day in Atlantic City. Were you my shadow, Agent Hobbes? Whoever it was, I must admit he was rather good, I couldn’t make head or tail of him... Dylan’s face is tight. He says nothing, biting down his embarrassment, as Thaddeus continues: THADDEUS (CONT’D) In any case, it’s your job to make the case stick. I’m here to tell you what I know , which at present is a hell of a lot more than you do. (turns to Agent Fuller) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THADDEUS (CONT’D) -And to spare you the price of a discount DVD: the new phones were simply slipped into the audience’s bags and pockets when they passed through “security”; an illusionist might employ a dozen such sleight of hand artists and cutpurses at any given show.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER
dialogues.text: I might be a rube, but even I kinda figured that. In fact this whole Tressler thing wasn’t all that much of a trick, you ask me.

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: It wasn’t meant to be. It’s called the “Mezzo”-a kind of entre-acte. Not particularly impressive on its own, but designed to get the audience on your side- which they certainly have succeeded in doing- while laying the groundwork for a final denouement.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER
dialogues.text: What I don’t get is why they’re doing all this and not keeping any of the money.

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: The Four Horsemen’s methods might be mysterious, but their motives are not. They’re not after wealth. They’re after fame, immortality. To be mentioned in the same breath as Robert-Houdin, Hermann, Houdini. (pauses) But who would risk life in prison only to remain anonymous in success? This fifth Horseman- and there is a fifth, without a doubt- his motives are as mysterious as his methods.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: You know what I don’t buy? Your motives. You told us you want to be relevant- but what you are is hated. You break the code of your own kind every day, and for what? A few bucks, fifteen minutes of fame? Don’t you have any sense of honor?  65.

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: Is there something you love, Agent Hobbes? That you would protect even at the expense of your own happiness or reputation? Dylan gives no answer. Thaddeus continues: THADDEUS (CONT’D) There is a legend- nothing we magic types love more than a good legend- of a secret sect of magicians that existed at the beginnings of our order’s inception. Perhaps as long ago as ancient Mesopotamia. This sect was known as “The Eye”- (smiles) -Where did you think the Masons got it from? “The Eye” was a cult within a cult; a secret society whose task it was to uphold the honor of the craft- something like your own Internal Affairs Department, yes? And when a rogue magician overstepped his bounds, or misused his craft, it was the task of The Eye to bring him down in a manner that would restore the honor of the order. Thaddeus’s voice is low, but his emotions are boiling: THADDEUS (CONT’D) Most of my “kind” as you put it, have devolved into a shameful lot of showboating Hollywood wannabes and Las Vegas whores. They have turned magic into vulgar pornography. Unfortunately, there is no secret order to protect my beloved art, so I have taken that onerous task upon my own shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: For a six figure television deal.

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: Fire with fire, Agent Hobbes. Alma has entered the doorway, a sheaf of papers in her ha  66.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: How about we protect our reputation as law enforcement officers, before these guys make us look like a bunch of rank amateurs again? (then) While you’ve been killing valuable time giving each other the macho stare-down, I found something you should see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma is standing in front of several COMPUTERS, sheaves o paper scattered all around her, as the others look on:

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: I used the bureau’s codes to trace every account Tressler had stashed his ill gotten gains in... amazing, the access you guys have, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, thanks to Osama. We got in there after 9-11, and never left.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER
dialogues.text: Why we vote Republican.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: Right. In any case, among many other banks around the world, Arthur Tressler has a fairly significant account with Credit Lyonnais.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Among many other banks.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: But he only has a secure safety deposit box in one.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER
dialogues.text: Arthur Tressler has a safety deposit box in Paris? In the bank branch the Four Horsemen robbed?

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: I, of course, do not have the authority to have it searched. You, on the other hand...  67. Dylan smiles admiringly at Alma:

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: -Are about to turn the lights up on the Four Horsemen’s little party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RODERIGO SANTAYANA is surrounded by silicon BLONDES, doin body shots. ALEX HERO is next to him, chatting up a prett girl; TITLE READS: Skybar - Los Angeles - California

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Girl, I am not talking about hip hop. I’m talking about R&B- romance. I steal your heart, baby. Album cover is like, got one hand like this- (covers the girl’s breast with his hand) The other is holding the Ace of Hearts, you know, like that shit was your heart, and I stole it. Alex feels another body, turns to find himself facing an attractive BRITISH WOMAN; a CAMERAMAN with a small CAMERA behind her:

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH WOMAN
dialogues.text: Alex- I’m Thelma Jones, from Sky News. Would you-

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Sorry ma’am, this is a business- free zone, know what I mean? You want an interview, call-

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH WOMAN
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, do you know what I had to do to get the bouncer to let us in here? Show us a little magic, won’t you, love? Alex holds his fingers to his head, squeezes his eyes shu

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: My powers tell me... you’re wearing red underwear with pink lace.  68.

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH WOMAN
dialogues.text: I didn’t know you were a mentalist, too.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I’m not. He HOLDS UP the pair of RED PANTIES -- The British Woman’ eyes open wide; she checks under her dress, then gasps in disbelief, and:

dialogues.speaker: LONDON
dialogues.text: That’1l be enough of that. London takes the underwear from Alex’s hand and gives it to the British Woman; turns back to Alex: LONDON (CONT’D) It’s time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL ATLAS is standing at the pay-phone, speaking as c whizz by on Sunset Boulevard:

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL ATLAS
dialogues.text: Just give me the word, and we’re on. (listens; and) Alright. Fired up, ready to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael signs a few AUTOGRAPHS as he makes his way toward elevators; hands a KID an extra napkin and says-—

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL ATLAS
dialogues.text: Hey, see that guy over there, at the bar? Can you give this to him? THE KID nods, hurries to a MAN sitting at the bar, sippin Martini, and hands him the napkin; the man unfolds it, se there’s a TWENTY DOLLAR BILL in there, and written on the napkin: HAVE ONE ON ME, Mr. G-MAN - NIGHTY NIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael steps inside, then stops in the foyer as he sees: LONDON OSBORNE, RODERIGO and ALEX HERO all are there wait for him.  69.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL ATLAS
dialogues.text: Let yourself in, why don’t you? (no answer) I detect an Ides of March vibe in here. Are you hiding daggers under your sleeves?

dialogues.speaker: LONDON
dialogues.text: Who is he? Michael knew this was coming; he sighs, shaking his head:

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL ATLAS
dialogues.text: We’ve been through this. I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: When I was a young apprentice touring with Reynaldino, he found out his daughter was slipping into my room. One morning in Las Carnes I went to the outhouse to do what you do in an outhouse. When I opened the door I found myself in Carboneras, two hundred kilometers away. Took me three years to figure out how he did that. I swore from that day on I would be the one pulling the strings. I don’t like this.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL ATLAS
dialogues.text: Don’t like what? Being the talk of the entire world? Famous beyond your wildest dreams? (real emotion seeping in) You know what I remember about my youth? TV dinners. Reruns. Volume turned up to drown out my parents’ squabble du jour. Trying to make myself be small, to disappear. To be nothing. That’s what I swore I’d never go back to. (pauses) No one will ever forget what we’re doing, as long as magic is talked about. The others watch Michael simmer down. They’ve never seen like this; then:  70. MICHAEL ATLAS (CONT’D) The Horsemen was his idea. He brought me in, and I came to you. He’s done everything he said he would, to aT. And his only stipulation was anonymity.

dialogues.speaker: LONDON
dialogues.text: That’s a big bloody stipulation.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL ATLAS
dialogues.text: He was right there with you in Atlantic City, wearing my face. If you’re so concerned, you should have asked him yourself.

dialogues.speaker: LONDON
dialogues.text: I did. He told me to sod off.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: London tried to put the stare on him, too... guy laughed in his face. Some funny shit, homes.

dialogues.speaker: LONDON
dialogues.text: Whoever this bloke is, he’s good. And plugged in as hell. Everything he told us to say to provoke those Feds was spot on. Got them hot to trot like greyhounds on a hare.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL ATLAS
dialogues.text: So what’s the problem?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: It’s all been good so far, but we're about to get into the big money. How do we know he’s not setting us up to eat it this time.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL ATLAS
dialogues.text: We don’t.

dialogues.speaker: LONDON
dialogues.text: Makes it bloody dangerous, mate.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL ATLAS
dialogues.text: Bloody dangerous. And bloody fun. (then) Are the Four Horsemen going out on a cute credit scam trick -- or are we going out on top of the world?  71. The others consider Michael’s words, then:

dialogues.speaker: LONDON
dialogues.text: Top o’ the world, Ma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IMAGES OF A SECURITY BOX- shot from every angle- appear i various sizes on a SERIES OF MONITORS; a forensic agent’s

dialogues.speaker: FORENSICS AGENT, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Magnified images show the lock was jimmied. Hardly a scratch. Good work. They definitely got in there. Dylan, Alma Vargas, Agent Fuller, Thaddeus Bradley and a handful of FBI AGENTS are studying the images on the scre

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER
dialogues.text: And what the hell was in there? Alma reads from a printed out list:

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: A couple of diamond rings- the kind you give a girl you want to convince of your intentions. Ora couple of girls. A watch with his father’s inscription on it. A letter from an ex-wife. And that, as they say, is all she wrote.

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: They did not break into that box only to leave everything in it intact. There has to be something you’re missing.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: You’re right about that. In fact, I had them go over the base of the box with one of those “scientific instruments we’re so proud of”- an infra-blue scanner. IMAGES OF THE BOTTOM OF THE BOX appear on the MONITOR; th is an IMPRINT VISIBLE -- LINES THAT LOOK LIKE A CORNER FR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DYLAN (CONT’D) Residue from blueprints of some kind. Printed on good old fashioned carbon paper. (to Thaddeus) See, around here, we do real magic.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: Blueprints for what?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Impossible to tell, with the little we've got. What about the numbers? A YOUNG AGENT turns from the screen he is studying:

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Last ID numbers of every Federal Building in California. Where’s their. .?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Their next show is in LA- tomorrow night. But that doesn’t mean much. They pulled off their robberies a good distance away from their shows both times, and-

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS
dialogues.text: Actually, the second location was a good deal closer than the first. Their preparation time for this one will be even less, and wherever they’re planning to...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG AGENT
dialogues.text: The money factory.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: The what?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG AGENT
dialogues.text: The Federal Reserve Printing House, in Salinas. It’s about twenty miles East of Downtown LA. Last number before the code is cut off matches... He types a few keys, and all the screens show “THE MONEY FACTORY”- A SQUAT, INDUSTRIAL BUILDING situated in the mi of a humdrum neighborhood.  73.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER
dialogues.text: How much money does a place like that print? The Young Agent types again, and:

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG AGENT
dialogues.text: Eight. Hundred. Million. Cash. Every day. No such facility has ever been compromised -- Ever. The agents fall silent. Then:

dialogues.speaker: AGENT FULLER
dialogues.text: These guys got some balls on ‘em. EXT. ARTHUR TRESSLER’S MANSION - DAY There are several UNMARKED CARS in the driveway, the occu of the mansion being under house arrest; on the SOUNDTRAC

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Tell us about the money factory. INT. LIVING ROOM - TRESSLER’S MANSION - CONTINUOUS Arthur Tressler is seated in front of a lavish fireplace, seething, as he faces Dylan and Alma Vargas:

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR TRESSLER
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you’re talking about.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: We followed your money, found your account at the Credit Lyonnais in Paris. We also found your security deposit box there, and what was in it.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR TRESSLER
dialogues.text: You went into my private box? There are laws that-

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: We didn’t go into it. The French did, under the blanket of financial terrorism laws too complicated for me to-

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR TRESSLER
dialogues.text: -So what? So you found my father’s watch...  74.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: -And two rings.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR TRESSLER
dialogues.text: There’s more than one pretty girl in Paris.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: And the blueprints for the Money Factory.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR TRESSLER
dialogues.text: I swear to Christ, I do not know what that is.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: The Federal Reserve Printing House, in Salinas. We also traced payments to employees who work at that facility, cleverly funneled so as not to compromise their identities. (then) Were you siphoning freshly printed money from the US government, Mr. Tressler?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR TRESSLER
dialogues.text: I was not. I am being set up by those four goddamn magicians, you morons.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA VARGAS
dialogues.text: Maybe, maybe not. If you’1ll excuse me for saying so, you’re a hard man to trust, Mr. Tressler.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: There is, however, one thing we do know with certainty -- The only way to breach a facility like that is with someone on the inside. We want the names of the employees you sent money to, and we want them now.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR TRESSLER
dialogues.text: I told you, I have no idea what you’re talking about. The Horsemen were able to access my account -- they could be paying whoever they want to with my money. (hard) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR TRESSLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want to find these guys, you’re gonna have to do it yourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC BLASTS through the windows -- MOTORCYCLES are parke a row in front; this is as openly bad-ass a bar as can be imagined, and LONDON OSBORNE steps into FRAME: walking toward the bar, listening to the voice in his ear-piece:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: You find it?

dialogues.speaker: LONDON
